comment._content: Edith Rockefeller McCormick (August 31, 1872 – August 25, 1932), the fourth daughter of John D. Rockefeller and his wife, Laura Spelman. She was a socialite and opera patron. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Edith_Rockefeller_McCormick She was the first wife of Harold Fowler McCormick. They married in 1895 and divorced in 1921. (en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Harold_Fowler_McCormick). Date on photo: 10/3/21 - the photo was obviously made on occasion of the separation from her husband. See e.g. article in The Washington times., October 07, 1921, FINAL HOME EDITION, Page 8, col. 1 & 2. Another photo in The Bismarck tribune., October 26, 1921, Image 1

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Todd Protzmann Davis, the author of villaturicum.blogspot.com/2011_04_01_archive.html believes that the picture was taken in the 1900-1910 period. And the dress looks a better fit with that date than 1921 -- which could be a date when the picture was used. The photo shown in the blog post is not damaged like Bain's. He also has a 1921 photo in a dress more typical of that date villaturicum.blogspot.com/2011/05/edith-in-1921.html

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: The Washington times., March 12, 1908, Last Edition, Page 9 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84026749/1908-03-12/ed-... features a cropped version of this picture with a copyright date of 1904 (copyright by H. W. Sierichs, secretary). And I think I can read that same date and attribution at top right of this picture.

comment.author: 23103743@N05
comment._content: Following up on Sierichs, I find The St. Louis Republic. (St. Louis, Mo.), 29 Jan. 1904. Page 3, col 2 chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84020274/1904-01-29/ed-... a report that selected men and women had been approached through letters from H.W. Sierichs to see if they would agree to have photographic portraits made by "leading photographers" for exhibition at the St. Louis World's Fair. Bain seemed to be behind the plan. The piece suggests that the exhibit for portraits of men was not accepted by the Fair organizers. I have not yet managed to confirm whether the exhibit of women's portraits materialized. Since Sierichs (or Bain) paid for the portraits that were taken, it would certainly make sense that he claimed the copyright. I hypothesize that this picture of Edith Rockefeller McCormick was taken as part of this program. There appears to be a photographer's signature followed by Chicago at lower right. LoC has at least one more portrait copyrighted by Sierichs in 1904, of Miss F.A. Kelley www.loc.gov/pictures/resource/cph.3c25752/
